summary: UPEC is one of the most common bacteria that can cause urinary tract infections (UTIs) no human vaccine has been developed. the use of lactic acid bacteria as a delivery system is a promising method to induce the immune system. the expression of PapG and PapG.AcmA proteins in the E. coli Origami strain was indicated as protein bands in SDS-PAGE and confirmed by western blotting. this is the first report on the successful application of lactic acid bacteria displaying the PapG.AcmA protein. UPEC bacteria establish UTIs and the presence of PapG promotes the progression of the infection to a more severe form, called pyelonephritis (4, 9). current treatment of acute UTI is limited due to the increasing rate of antibiotic-resistant strains as well as adverse effects of vaccines. papG gene segment containing histidine tag was designed, synthesized by Bioneer. pEXA vector was transformed into E. coli DH5 cells using calcium chloride method. plasmid purifications were carried out on transformed bacteria. the fidelity of the pET21a/PapG-AcmA vector was confirmed using the standard calcium chloride protocol. pET21a/PapG-AcmA and pET21a/PapG vectors were transformed using the standard calcium chloride protocol. protein expression was confirmed by western blotting using anti-his antibodies. the cell pellet was suspended in buffer A (20 mM Tris-HCl, 0.5 M NaCl, 0.3% Triton X100, 1 mM PMSF, 10 mM imidazole, pH 8.0) the suspension was centrifuged (12,000 rpm, 20 minutes, 4°C) the sample was loaded on a Ni-NTA column. ELISA plates were coated overnight at 4°C by L. reuteri. plates were blocked with 3% PBS-BSA for 2 hours at 37°C. then 100 L of anti his-tag monoclonal antibody was added to each well. the purified plasmid was digested with NdeI and BamHI enzymes. the recombinant plasmid was double digested with NdeI/BamHI enzymes. electrophoresis was carried out on a 1% agarose gel. recombinant papG and papG-AcmA proteins were confirmed with western blotting. recombinant papG and papG-AcmA proteins were further confirmed with western blotting. the suspension was centrifuged (12,000 rpm, 20 minutes, 4°C) the sample was loaded on a Ni-NTA column (Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA) the concentration of each protein was detected via the Bradford method. plates were washed and 100 L of a 1/10,000 dilution of the anti-mouse horseradish peroxidase conjugate antibody was added to each well. after washing 5 times, 100 L of a dilution of the anti-mouse horseradish peroxidase conjugate antibody was added for 90 minutes at 37°C. s showed a 629-bp band using gel electrophoresis.
